learning.explanation: Most modern twin-engine aircraft use a split-bus AC distribution, whereas with 3 or 4 engines, the system can have a little more backup available, and can use a parallel-bus distribution. This is where, the same as split-bus, each generator feeds its corresponding load bus bar. The difference is that AC LOAD BUS 1 and AC LOAD BUS 2 are "tied" under normal operation, and the generators are paralleled to each other to make this work. The same goes for generators and AC LOAD BUS bars 3 and 4. The left hand synchronising bus ties AC LOAD BUS 1 and AC LOAD BUS 2 together, whilst the right hand synchronising bus ties AC LOAD BUS 3 and AC BUS 4 together. Both synchronising busses can be tied together using the SSB (split-system breaker) if required to balance a load with a generator failure. This would, however, mean that all remaining generators would have to be paralleled to each other, as any time multiple generators feed the same bus bar, they must be paralleled to each other (same voltage, frequency and phase).

key_points: The system that checks for faults in the AC generator is the Generator Control Unit (GCU)

learning.explanation: The system that checks for faults in the AC generator is the Generator Control Unit (GCU). Upon detection of a dangerous situation in the generator; which could be over-excitation or overvoltage; the GCU will open the exciter control relay which will protect the generator from potential further damage. At the same time, the GCU will also open the generator circuit breaker (GCB) to disconnect the generator from its bus bar. On the attached diagram ( you have the engine fire and open feeder protection and differential current protection schematics of the Airbus A320. As you can see, the Generator Control Unit (GCU) is responsible for isolating the generator in case of malfunction or deactivation by the pilots. The GCU control and protection functions are mainly performed by internal relays: The Generator Control Relay (GCR) controls the excitation of the generator, equivalent to what is called in this question as to the exciter control relay. The Power Ready Relay (PRR) that controls the Generator Line Contactor (GCL), equivalent in this question as to the generator breaker open. And the ServoValve relay (SV) that controls the IDG speed. The diagram shows that if a protection function is triggered, such as the engine fire push button, the GCU will command the GCR (exciter control relay) will be de-energized to protect the generator from further damage. Additionally, the generator will be isolated from its onside bus bar by de-energizing the GCL (generator breaker open).

content.question: During start of an engine fitted with a brushless AC generator, the initial excitation is provided by...

options.A: the auxiliary winding.
options.B: the main field winding.
options.C: the stabiliser winding jointly with the voltage regulator.
options.D: a set of permanent magnets.

key_points: Modern brushless AC generators contain an exciter generator mounted on the same shaft as the main generator
The exciter generator consisting of a set of permanent magnets will provide an initial excitation current for the main generator rotating field

When the generator is running, the voltage regulator will send a DC field current to the excitor stator to supplement the magnetic field of the permanent magnets, and allow the generator's output to be controlled
learning.explanation: Modern brushless AC generators contain an exciter generator mounted on the same shaft as the main generator. The exciter generator consisting of a set of permanent magnets will provide an initial excitation current for the main generator rotating field. When the generator is running, the voltage regulator will send a DC field current to the excitor stator to supplement the magnetic field of the permanent magnets, and allow the generator's output to be controlled. The AC produced in the exciter armature will be converted into DC for the main rotor field supply in order to keep the polarity in the spinning rotor. This allows the motor to run without the need for brushes, thereby increasing lifespan. It also has a higher power to weight ratio than older methods of AC generation. There is a further addition that can be made to this system, where a third smaller generator exists on the same shaft, which has a set of spinning permanent magnets and a stationary armature. The current from the armature is rectified to provide power to the generator control systems, and to the stationary field coils of the excitation generator, and effectively takes the permanent magnets from the older style brushless AC generator, and puts them in a different place (a small thrid generator), serving a similar purpose. This can improve efficiency, and these more modern types of AC generators are also called Permanent Magnet Generators. Whichever type of AC generator that is being asked about, they both use permanent magnets for their intial excitation.

content.question: In an electrical system where a permanent magnet is usually used to initiate rotation, which of the following could alternatively be used in its place to achieve a similar result?

options.A: A DC electromagnet, which uses direct current to create a magnetic field.
options.B: An AC induction coil, utilizing alternating current to induce rotation without direct contact.
options.C: A mechanical starter, requiring physical force to begin the rotation.
options.D: A piezoelectric actuator, which converts electrical signals into physical movement.

key_points: A permanent magnet is an object which always creates a certain magnetic field around itself, without any power input or movement, etc
This is often used as the very initial generation of electricity within a generator when it begins spinning
The constant magnetic field of a permanent magnet can be recreated instead by passing a current (a direct current, to produce a constant magnetic field) through a coil of wire
learning.explanation: A permanent magnet is an object which always creates a certain magnetic field around itself, without any power input or movement, etc. This is often used as the very initial generation of electricity within a generator when it begins spinning. The constant magnetic field of a permanent magnet can be recreated instead by passing a current (a direct current, to produce a constant magnetic field) through a coil of wire. The question isn't exact about the scenario here, but there is only one answer which correctly imitates a permanent magnet.

content.question: What's the purpose of bundling cables and wires together on an aircraft?

options.A: Stronger against bending (e.g. say a door closed on the cable).
options.B: Reduce chance of thermal runaway and/or fire.
options.C: Magnetic induction/disturbance.
options.D: Easier for maintenance.

learning.explanation: 021.09.01.06.05: Explain the principle of electromagnetic induction and how two electrical components or systems may affect each other through this principle. Magnetic disturbance occurs when an external electromagnetic field induces an unwanted current or voltage in an electrical circuit. This phenomenon can lead to errors or malfunctions within the affected circuit. Sources of magnetic disturbance vary and can include radio frequency transmissions, power lines, and other electrical equipment Magnetic induction describes the process whereby a magnetic field induces an electromotive force (EMF) in a conductor that either moves relative to the magnetic field or experiences a changing magnetic field passing through it. Bundling cables and wires together on an aircraft helps mitigate the risk of magnetic induction or disturbance. When wires are arranged in close proximity but properly shielded and bundled, they can reduce electromagnetic interference (EMI) and minimize the impact of magnetic fields generated by various electrical systems onboard.

content.question: Electrical power can be defined as...

options.A: the formula 'voltage × current × time'.
options.B: electrical energy which is converted into another form of energy.
options.C: the rate of doing work.
options.D: the unit 'J', the abbreviation for Joule.

key_points: Power is the rate of "doing work"
It can also be described as the rate of energy transfer, which is the same thing
Power = Energy Transferred / Time Power is therefore a measure of how much energy is being transferred into another form per second
learning.explanation: Power is the rate of "doing work". It can also be described as the rate of energy transfer, which is the same thing. Power = Energy Transferred / Time Power is therefore a measure of how much energy is being transferred into another form per second. It is measured in Watts (W). It is sometimes useful to rearrange this equation to read: Energy Transferred = Power x Time In electrical terms, and this applies to any transfer of energy which goes through electrical energy (generators, motors, etc.), the power can also be calculated using the equation: Power = Voltage x Current The amount of energy transferred is therefore (putting the two formulas together): Energy = Voltage x Current x Time To address the other possible answers, voltage x current x time = energy, not power. It is not just when electrical enegry is transferred to another form of energy, it can also be the other way around. Joules is a unit of energy, not power.

content.question: Which of the following is a risk associated with Lithium batteries?

options.A: A short-circuit when the electrolyte comes into contact with the electrodes.
options.B: Release of flammable gases when they are discharged at too high of a rate.
options.C: Self-ignition when the charging process is NOT properly controlled.
options.D: Corrosion of the grounding wire attached to the metal airframe.

key_points: The biggest threat to Lithium-ion batteries is thermal runaway
Thermal runaway of the lithium-ion battery initiates an unstoppable chain reaction
The temperature rises rapidly within milliseconds and the energy stored in the battery is suddenly released
learning.explanation: The biggest threat to Lithium-ion batteries is thermal runaway. Thermal runaway of the lithium-ion battery initiates an unstoppable chain reaction. The temperature rises rapidly within milliseconds and the energy stored in the battery is suddenly released. Several factors can lead to thermal runaway of a lithium-ion battery: Internal short circuit: Due to an accident or similar mechanical impact, e.g. if a tool falls down from a great height, the battery is deformed, material penetrates the battery cell and triggers an internal short circuit. External short circuit: Deformation of the battery cell causes an external short circuit. Overcharging the battery beyond the maximum voltage specified in the data sheet. Depending on the degree of overcharging, the battery may be damaged permanently and the service life of the battery decreases. Overheating/Excessive currents when charging. Recharging a Li-ion battery will cause the temperature of the battery to increase.

Refer to figure.
On ground, APU GEN can be used to feed both AC BUS 1 and AC BUS 2, when: (NB: all contactors not mentioned are assumed to remain open)

options.D: C1.1, C2.1 and C2.2 are closed.

1, and C2

content.question: In an AC power generation system, the constant speed drive unit is…

options.A: an electronic unit that can be disconnected from the engine drive shaft during flight.
options.B: an electronic unit that cannot be disconnected from the engine drive shaft during flight.
options.C: a hydromechanical unit that can be disconnected from the engine drive shaft during flight.
options.D: a hydromechanical unit that cannot be disconnected from the engine drive shaft during flight.

key_points: An AC generator driven by a constant speed unit is also known as a Constant Speed Generator Drive System, CSDU, or CSD
The main function of this system is to maintain a constant frequency, sometimes referred to as speed
In other words, it is a hydromechanical unit that turns the physical motion of oil/fluid into an AC or DC current
learning.explanation: An AC generator driven by a constant speed unit is also known as a Constant Speed Generator Drive System, CSDU, or CSD. The main function of this system is to maintain a constant frequency, sometimes referred to as speed. In other words, it is a hydromechanical unit that turns the physical motion of oil/fluid into an AC or DC current. The output of the hydraulic motor, and therefore the speed of the motor is dictated by the angle of the swashplate. The angle of the swash plate will either limit or increase the oil flow towards the hydraulic and in turn affect the rpm of the engine. The angle of the swash plate is controlled by the speed governor, which in turn is controlled by the load controller. The load controller senses the output frequency of the alternator and will adjust the swash plate accordingly to increase or decrease the torque output to the generator. The CSD can be disconnected from the engine drive shaft at any time during the flight. However, only the engineers can reconnect the CSD, on the ground, with the engines off.

content.question: Why should a group of wires be covered in one loop and protection shield?

options.A: So that the cable becomes one single loop connected to the Earth.
options.B: In order to have a bigger overall resistance and less energy waste.
options.C: In order to provide less resistance and more flexibility.
options.D: For better protection under high load.

key_points: A cable is usually made up of a conductor composed of a group of single solid wires stranded together to provide greater flexibility and enclosed in insulating material and outer protective covering
learning.explanation: A cable is usually made up of a conductor composed of a group of single solid wires stranded together to provide greater flexibility and enclosed in insulating material and outer protective covering.

content.question: In flight, if the Constant Speed Drive (CSD) temperature indicator is in the red arc the…

options.A: pilot must disconnect it, and the generator is not available for the rest of flight.
options.B: pilot has to throttle back.
options.C: pilot must disconnect it and manually control the alternator.
options.D: pilot can disconnect it to allow it to cool and use it again.

key_points: A Constant Speed Drive Unit (CSDU) is a hydraulic-mechanical unit adapting the speed of the generator to maintain a constant frequency
As the engine speed is continuously hanging, so would the output frequency, but the CSD unit alters the output torque to keep the generator running at a constant frequency
The system is connected to the engine through a dog clutch release mechanism
learning.explanation: A Constant Speed Drive Unit (CSDU) is a hydraulic-mechanical unit adapting the speed of the generator to maintain a constant frequency. As the engine speed is continuously hanging, so would the output frequency, but the CSD unit alters the output torque to keep the generator running at a constant frequency. The system is connected to the engine through a dog clutch release mechanism. Whenever the CSD oil temperature is too high, oil pressure and/or level become too low, and the indicator will provide a warning in the cockpit and the pilots will be able to disconnect the CSD. After disconnection, the CSD unit can only be reconnected on the ground by the engineers.

content.question:
A relay with a low current is being used to control a circuit with a high current. Which of the following is correct?
1) The relay is physically connected to the circuit
2) The relay is not physically connected to the circuit
3) The control can be fed with DC and the high current circuit can be fed with AC

options.A: Only 1.
options.B: 1 and 3.
options.C: Only 3.
options.D: 2 and 3.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: There is a very similar question to this also, question 213212, which has the same options, but talks about "physical separation" rather than "physical connection", so is therefore the inverse of this question
We cannot be 100% sure that both questions exist separately, but feedback indicates it is possible, so be very careful in the exam to read and consider the question
Please try to remember which one you see in the exam so you can let us know in the comments if possible, thank you! Relays are widely used in aircraft electrical systems
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: There is a very similar question to this also, question 213212, which has the same options, but talks about "physical separation" rather than "physical connection", so is therefore the inverse of this question. We cannot be 100% sure that both questions exist separately, but feedback indicates it is possible, so be very careful in the exam to read and consider the question. Please try to remember which one you see in the exam so you can let us know in the comments if possible, thank you! Relays are widely used in aircraft electrical systems. They function as switches that use a small DC electrical current to open and close circuits carrying much larger currents (AC or DC), crucial for high-current systems operated by the crew. A small wire coil wound around a ferromagnetic core forms an electromagnet. When activated by a modest current, the electromagnet closes a switch with a hinged metallic arm that it pulls shut. When the current is switched off, the magnetic field disappears, and a spring forces the switch contacts to open. We are therefore using a very safe smaller circuit as a switch so we don't have to go anywhere near high current AC circuits, allowing them to be kept away from the flight deck, etc. The relay is physically separated (air gap/insulation) from the main circuit as otherwise the high current of the main circuit would fry the low rated relay circuit 2) The relay is not physically connected to the circuit. - Correct As mentioned above. 3) The control can be fed with DC and the high current circuit can be fed with AC. - Correct The relay’s contacts are isolated from the control coil, enabling them to handle different types of currents. DC is required for the relay (control circuit) as it needs to keep the electromagnet on at a specific strength. AC or DC can be used by the main circuit, but AC is more common.

content.question: You are flying an aircraft in which all the generators have failed, but you still have battery power. What should be considered?

options.A: The batteries have a limited charge, so electrical components will not be able to operate indefinitely.
options.B: There are no special considerations since all components previously powered by the generators will receive power from the batteries automatically.
options.C: The most important instrument to be monitored now is the temperature of the batteries to avoid any thermal runaway.
options.D: All electrical components will become unusable for the remainder of the flight.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.02.01.08: State that in the case of loss of all generated power (battery power only) the remaining electrical power is time-limited. When an aircraft does run out of working generators, it is a very high risk scenario. The onboard batteries are powerful enough to feed the essential and emergency DC and AC busses, via an inverter (as batteries produce DC), but they only have a limited amount of charge stored. The batteries should be usable for 30 minutes running essential and emergency (vital) systems from a fully charged state. This is the reason that most aircraft are not allowed to fly with only 1 working generator, because if that fails, the aircraft is in the very bad situation described above.

content.question: A conductor is positioned in a magnetic field perpendicular to the magnetic field lines. If a current is passed through this conductor…

options.A: the intensity of the magnetic field will decrease.
options.B: a force will be exerted on the conductor.
options.C: there will be no effect unless the conductor is moved.
options.D: the current will increase.

key_points: This question refers to the Lorentz force that is exerted on a charged particle moving through an electric or magnetic field
Several elements are a must to create the Lorentz force: Firstly the conductor through which the charged particles pass (electrons) must be perpendicular to the magnetic field lines
There must be a current flowing through the conductor, or else no force will be exerted
learning.explanation: This question refers to the Lorentz force that is exerted on a charged particle moving through an electric or magnetic field. Several elements are a must to create the Lorentz force: Firstly the conductor through which the charged particles pass (electrons) must be perpendicular to the magnetic field lines. There must be a current flowing through the conductor, or else no force will be exerted. The conductor must be positioned in either a magnetic or electric field. Be careful! Do not confuse “charged particles moving through an electric or magnetic field” with the conductor moving through an electric field. The electrons that are creating the current consist of moving charged particles, therefore the conductor does not need to be moved for a Lorentz force to be created.

content.question: Why is braided wire built into some electrical cables?

options.A: As an alternative to traditional nylon/rubber cable coverings.
options.B: To increase the conductance/reduce the resistance of the wire.
options.C: To protect the cable from electromagnetic induction from other electrical systems.
options.D: To amplify the size of the electromagnetic field, as current passes through the wire.

key_points: Braided wire is a type of shielding that gets built into a cable for two reasons: To protect the cable from electromagnetic interference (EMI)
To increase the flex life and mechanical strength of a cable
The shielding looks just as you would imagine; several fine wires tightly woven into a meshed tubular formation that wraps around a conductor
learning.explanation: Braided wire is a type of shielding that gets built into a cable for two reasons: To protect the cable from electromagnetic interference (EMI). To increase the flex life and mechanical strength of a cable. The shielding looks just as you would imagine; several fine wires tightly woven into a meshed tubular formation that wraps around a conductor. Braided wire tubing can also be flattened to achieve a specific width. Overtop is a thin insulating outer layer that covers and protects the braided wire and the internal components of the cable.

content.question: A battery capacity of 10 Ah means that the battery can provide...

options.A: 5 Amperes for 1 hour.
options.B: 5 Amperes for 5 hours.
options.C: 5 Amperes for 2 hours.
options.D: 5 Amperes for 20 minutes.

key_points: Batteries convert chemical energy into electrical energy by a transfer of electrons from one material to another using the potential difference between the materials
The capacity of a battery is the amount of Ampere-hour (Ah) a fully charged battery can supply
For example, a 5Ah capacity means that the battery will be able to deliver 5 amperes in 1 hour or 2
learning.explanation: Batteries convert chemical energy into electrical energy by a transfer of electrons from one material to another using the potential difference between the materials. The capacity of a battery is the amount of Ampere-hour (Ah) a fully charged battery can supply. For example, a 5Ah capacity means that the battery will be able to deliver 5 amperes in 1 hour or 2.5 Amperes in 2 hours, or even 10 amperes in 30 minutes. That is, the current (A) multiplied by time (Hr) in hours equals ampere hours. A. 5 Amperes x 1 hours = 5 Ah (wrong) B. 5 Amperes x 5 hours = 25 Ah (wrong) C. 5 Amperes x 2 hours = 10 Ah (correct) D. 5 Amperes x 0.33 hours (20 minutes) = 1.65 Ah (wrong) If two identical batteries are connected in parallel the output voltage will remain the same and the capacity expressed in ampere-hours will double. On the other hand, if the batteries are connected in series, the capacity will remain the same, but the output voltage will double.

content.question: A 3 phase AC generator has 3 separate stator windings spaced at:

key_points: When three groups of coils are fitted independently to the same armature, three different slip rings will be connected, and three different voltages will be generated
One coil starts at 120° to the start of the next one, and the three generated voltages differ in phase by 120°
When one stator winding’s voltage is at its peak value, the voltage in the others is at half peak value in the opposite direction, therefore the sum of the three voltage results as zero
learning.explanation: When three groups of coils are fitted independently to the same armature, three different slip rings will be connected, and three different voltages will be generated. One coil starts at 120° to the start of the next one, and the three generated voltages differ in phase by 120°. When one stator winding’s voltage is at its peak value, the voltage in the others is at half peak value in the opposite direction, therefore the sum of the three voltage results as zero.

content.question:
Which of the following statements is correct or incorrect related to an electric motor?
1. Mechanical torque (T) is directly proportional to the voltage (E) x current (I) and is inversely proportional to the strength of the generated magnetic field
2. Mechanical torque (T) is directly proportional to the voltage (E) divided by the current (I) and is directly proportional to the strength of the generated magnetic field

options.A: Both statements are correct.
options.B: 1 is incorrect; 2 is correct.
options.C: Both statements are incorrect.
options.D: 1 is correct; 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.05.02.01: Describe how the torque of an electrical motor is determined by the supplied voltage and current, and the resulting magnetic fields within the motor. There are 2 equations that will tell us what we need to know here, the first is: 1. Power = Voltage x Current In essence, the energy used per electron (voltage) x the amount of electrons passing per second (current) = the energy used per second (power). 2. Power = Torque x RPM All we need from this equation is to know that power and torque (turning force) are directly proportional (RPM is not mentioned in this question, so it can be assumed to stay the same) Then a simple knowledge of how motors work, a current moving across (perpendicular to) an electric field creates force (torque): The stronger the current, or the stronger the electric field, the more the force (torque). Therefore, the torque is directly proportional to the strength of the magnetic field. (There is an equation for this, Force = Field Strength x Current, but it is easier to just think it out than to remember the formula). Now to check each statement: 1) Mechanical torque is proportional to the voltage x current and is inversely proportional to the strength of the generated field. The first part is correct, Voltage x Current = Power, which is directly proportional to torque. The second part is incorrect, torque is directly proportional to the strength of the magnetic field. 2) Mechanical torque is proportional to the voltage divided by the current and is proportional to the strength of the generated magnetic field. This is the exact opposite to the first one, and therefore the first part is incorrect; voltage divided by current will not be proportional to torque, but the second part is correct. Neither statement is completely correct, so both are incorrect. Note: E is used as the notation for voltage due to a thing called EMF, or electromotive force, and is the way voltage is referred to in motors. I is the standard notation for current.

content.question: In a DC electric motor with stator and rotor coils in series, an armature runaway will cause the current in the armature to...

options.A: increase, but because the current in the stator coil decreases, the torque will stay the same.
options.B: increase, and because the current in the stator coil also increases, the torque will increase.
options.C: decrease, and because the current in the stator coil also decreases, the torque will decrease.
options.D: decrease, but because the current in the stator coil increases, the torque will stay the same.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.05.02.03: Explain the consequences of the following: rotor seizure; rotor runaway. An easy way to think about these questions is by thinking that the motor is always trying to correct for the change. Rotor seizes, current and torque increase to try and get it going faster; Rotor runaway, current and torque decrease to try and slow down. Torque is directly set by the current, so they always move in the same direction. Try to remember the diagram, that both the field coils and the armature coils are in series, so the current changes the same way in both of them at the same time. You are supposed to know a little bit more than just this, but that should be enough for the current questions we know about. Longer explanation A series wound DC electric motor is intended to have a certain torque demands put on it. A "runaway" is where that torque demand disappears, and all of a sudden, the armature will be spinning freely. This will initially speed the armature up, as there is no longer much resistance to spinning. This increase in speed will lead to an increase in back EMF, which is effectively the "equal and opposite force" on a motor, that restricts the current flow. An increase in back EMF will mean that the current flow decreases (more restriction on current flow) through both the field coil and the armature coil, which will subsequently decrease the torque in the motor. Due to the rapidly increasing speed of the motor under no load, the reduction in torque is often not at a fast enough rate to stop an overspeed, and even destruction of the motor. This depends on what safety breakers/cut-offs are involved of course.

content.question: What happens once the pilot has operated the IDG (Integrated Drive Generator) disconnect button?

options.A: An electrical supply system will be lost.
options.B: A hydraulic supply system will be lost.
options.C: An electrical supply system will be lost, but can be reset in-flight.
options.D: The disconnect switch can be used to re-connect the IDG in-flight, after sufficient time for cooling the generator.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.03.03.04: Explain the consequences of a mechanical disconnection during flight for a CSD and an IDG. An integrated drive generator (IDG) consists of a Constant Speed Drive (CSD) unit and an electrical generator which are located inside one casing. As an IDG is a self contained system, the fault light in the cockpit can tell us of any problems, and sometimes there is a temperature dial that can tell us of an overheat in the lubricating oil, etc., which might require the IDG to be disconnected from the engine gearbox. If a pilot has to manually disconnect the IDG, they must operate the IDG disconnect switch. The IDG switch is guarded and normally spring loaded out. When operated, the IDG is disconnected from its drive shaft (mechanically breaks the link between the IDG and the engine gearbox) and can only be reconnected by maintenance, after engine shutdown. IDGs are able to automatically disconnect when a high oil temperature occurs, and therefore require no input from the pilot on this issue, but this will have the same effect as manually disconnecting the IDG, which means that the in-built generator will be unusable for the rest of the flight, and can only be re-connected on the ground by engineers, so that electrical supply is unavailable for the remainder of the flight.

content.question: A current limiter fuse in a DC system is used to…

options.A: limit the current in the armature.
options.B: allow a short term overload before rupturing.
options.C: allow no overload before rupturing.
options.D: limit the current in the field circuit.

key_points: Current limiters’ purpose is to allow the current flow into a circuit only up to a pre-determined amperage value
These fuses usually consist of a single copper strip enclosed in a rectangular ceramic housing, having a glass (or mica) inspection window
They are perforated and shaped at each end to form lug-type connections, with the central portion narrowed to properly fit the fusing area
learning.explanation: Current limiters’ purpose is to allow the current flow into a circuit only up to a pre-determined amperage value. These fuses usually consist of a single copper strip enclosed in a rectangular ceramic housing, having a glass (or mica) inspection window. They are perforated and shaped at each end to form lug-type connections, with the central portion narrowed to properly fit the fusing area. The current limiter fuses are not like the ordinary fuses as they have a rather high melting point in order to be able to carry higher short-term current overload before breaking. Therefore, they are mainly designed to be used in the protection of heavy-duty power distribution circuits, such as the output of transformer rectifier unit (TRU) for example.

content.question: The pilot detectes a low oil pressure in the Integrated Drive Generator (IDG). The pilot…

options.A: Must reduce thrust on the associated engine and wait for the oil pressure to rise again.
options.B: Must pull the corresponding circuit breaker (CB).
options.C: Must use the generator control switch.
options.D: Must operate IDG disconnect switch.

key_points: An integrated drive generator (IDG) consists of a Constant Speed Drive (CSD) unit and a generator which are located inside one casing
An amber FAULT light indicates an IDG oil outlet overheat or low oil pressure
When an IDG low oil pressure is detected, the pilot must operate the IDG disconnect push button
learning.explanation: An integrated drive generator (IDG) consists of a Constant Speed Drive (CSD) unit and a generator which are located inside one casing. An amber FAULT light indicates an IDG oil outlet overheat or low oil pressure. When an IDG low oil pressure is detected, the pilot must operate the IDG disconnect push button. The IDG switch is guarded and normally spring loaded out. When pushed, the IDG is disconnected from its drive shaft (mechanically breaks the link between the IDG and the engine gearbox) and can only be reconnected by maintenance, after engine shutdown.

content.question: A magnetic circuit-breaker…

options.A: permits an overcurrent limited in time.
options.B: is a protection system with a quick trip response time.
options.C: can be safely reset even when a fault remains.
options.D: is a protection system with a slow trip response time.

key_points: The circuit breakers combine the function of a fuse and a switch in one unit
They consist of an automatic thermo-sensitive tripping device and a manually or electrically operated switch
Therefore, besides providing protection to any AC or DC circuit, they can be used to switch a circuit on and off under certain circumstances
learning.explanation: The circuit breakers combine the function of a fuse and a switch in one unit. They consist of an automatic thermo-sensitive tripping device and a manually or electrically operated switch. Therefore, besides providing protection to any AC or DC circuit, they can be used to switch a circuit on and off under certain circumstances. Circuit breakers are special because even after the circuit breaker has blown, the circuit can be closed again, thus allowing to restore the circuit and potentially power important systems. We say that the circuit breaker is resettable The most common circuit breakers are the bimetallic and magnetic CBs. The bi-metallic CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together. The current flowing through the bonded metals will heat them and make them expand and bend. If the flowing current is too important, the strip will bend so much that it will move a latch tripping the circuit breaker and break the circuit. Because the functioning of the bi-metallic CB relays on the time it will take to heat it up there should be another solution that will be more responsive. That’s exactly what a magnetic CB is correcting. An abnormal increase of the circuit's current will act on an electromagnet in the circuit breaker and trip it immediately.

content.question: Assuming a constant speed drive (CSD) fault is indicated, the CSD should be disconnected…

options.A: provided the engine is running.
options.B: at flight idle engine rpm only.
options.C: when the AC generator voltage is outside limits.
options.D: on the ground only.

key_points: The system that is in charge of disconnecting the constant speed drive and or the alternator from the engine in case of a fault is the Drive Disconnect Unit
This system will cause the CSD and the alternator to stop moving, removing any danger or hazard of their movement
By also disconnecting the system from the engine, the system will prevent any malfunction to affect engine performance
learning.explanation: The system that is in charge of disconnecting the constant speed drive and or the alternator from the engine in case of a fault is the Drive Disconnect Unit. This system will cause the CSD and the alternator to stop moving, removing any danger or hazard of their movement. By also disconnecting the system from the engine, the system will prevent any malfunction to affect engine performance. The disconnect can and should be carried out any time the engine is running, whether on the ground, in the air, idle or max thrust. However, the engine can usually not be reconnected to the CSD until back on the ground and with the engine off.

content.question: Why do electrical wires need to be protected and insulated?

options.A: To better differentiate each cable.
options.B: To protect the wire from the solar radiation.
options.C: To avoid water from getting directly on the wire.
options.D: To avoid the current from escaping from the desired path of the wire, that could be dangerous to anyone getting in contact.

key_points: Electrical wires carry current, which can be simply described as a flow of electrons through the wire, from a place of high electrical potential, to a place of low electrical potential (the electrons actually flow from low to high, but the convention is to say that current flows from high to low)
Electricity always wants to flow to a point of lower potential, the same way that water always wants to flow downwards, and we need to make it so that it wants to go through the wires
This is why wires are insulated, as the resistance of the coating around the wire is very high, so there is no reason (or ability) for the electricity to flow anywhere other than down the wire
learning.explanation: Electrical wires carry current, which can be simply described as a flow of electrons through the wire, from a place of high electrical potential, to a place of low electrical potential (the electrons actually flow from low to high, but the convention is to say that current flows from high to low). Electricity always wants to flow to a point of lower potential, the same way that water always wants to flow downwards, and we need to make it so that it wants to go through the wires. This is why wires are insulated, as the resistance of the coating around the wire is very high, so there is no reason (or ability) for the electricity to flow anywhere other than down the wire. This protects us aswell, as it stops current flowing through us (an electric shock) when handling wires, as we do not touch the wires directly, only the outer coating. Protecting wires is done in a similar way, but this time it is to stop any corrosion or physical damage to the internal wiring, for instance when your phone charging cable breaks at the ends due to the constant bending, leavng the wire exposed. This can be stopped by using heavier protection around the wires.

Whereas with a DC generator (dynamo) the opposite is true: the field windings are on the stator and the induction windings of the armature are on the rotor
The main advantages of AC systems over DC systems are the following: Brushless, so require les maintenance and less costs
learning.explanation: The essential difference between aircraft AC alternators and DC generators is that, in an AC generator, the windings in which the output current induced (= the armature) are on the stator and are therefore fixed and the field windings are on the rotor. Whereas with a DC generator (dynamo) the opposite is true: the field windings are on the stator and the induction windings of the armature are on the rotor. The main advantages of AC systems over DC systems are the following: Brushless, so require les maintenance and less costs. More responsive to various operations. Lighter than DC generators. Better power to weight ratio. Voltage can be easily changed with transformers. Easy to convert AC into DC. Lower voltage produced at a lower RPM than dynamos.

content.question: It is NOT recommended to reset a tripped circuit breaker during flight because…

key_points: A circuit breaker is a thermally operated mechanical device that replaces the functions of a fuse and is today the most commonly used overload protection device
Once operated because of excess current, the device can be reset only once

If a circuit breaker trips while you’re flying, it’s okay to reset it after allowing a minute or two for it to cool, even if you have no idea what caused it to trip and cut off electrical power to a particular circuit
learning.explanation: A circuit breaker is a thermally operated mechanical device that replaces the functions of a fuse and is today the most commonly used overload protection device. Once operated because of excess current, the device can be reset only once. If a circuit breaker trips while you’re flying, it’s okay to reset it after allowing a minute or two for it to cool, even if you have no idea what caused it to trip and cut off electrical power to a particular circuit. Only if the breaker trips a second time should you not try to restore power by resetting it. Excessive resetting of the circuit and therefore allowing the potentially overcurrent to flow could damage systems and electrical damage could potentially become worse.

options.C: It is powered by the main battery via an inverter, to keep essential AC consumers running in the event of a total generation failure.
options.D: It is directly connected to the main battery to power essential aircraft controls and components.

key_points: Almost all aircraft require AC (alternating current) and DC (direct current) power for various consumers
All modern large jet aircraft generate power as AC, and any consumers that require DC are fed by a separate circuit of DC power
AC must be "rectified" into DC, and aircraft use transformer rectifier units (TRUs) to do this, as well as reducing the voltage to the correct level (usually 115 V AC to 28 V DC)
learning.explanation: Almost all aircraft require AC (alternating current) and DC (direct current) power for various consumers. All modern large jet aircraft generate power as AC, and any consumers that require DC are fed by a separate circuit of DC power. AC must be "rectified" into DC, and aircraft use transformer rectifier units (TRUs) to do this, as well as reducing the voltage to the correct level (usually 115 V AC to 28 V DC). This DC circuit is also what charges the batteries, as batteries can only use DC. This question asks about the other direction though, from DC to AC, assuming all the AC generators have failed and the aircraft batteries have a limited supply of DC power available. To power the AC components with DC, it must be "inverted", to turn the flat voltage of DC into a sine wave voltage of AC. A static inverter does this, so AC equipment can run off the DC battery in the event of an AC generation failure.

options.D: It will take too much time to detect an open circuit.

key_points: A fuse is a thermal circuit protection device which protects distribution system cables and components against excessive electrical currect when failures occur

Fuses are rated to a specific maximum current specified in amperes and will rupture (meaning that the fusible will melt and open the circuit) at a slightly higher value to accomodate surge as a load is switched on and is in series with the load it protects
If you replace a fuse with a higher amp one it will work but create an unsafe circuit
learning.explanation: A fuse is a thermal circuit protection device which protects distribution system cables and components against excessive electrical currect when failures occur. Fuses are rated to a specific maximum current specified in amperes and will rupture (meaning that the fusible will melt and open the circuit) at a slightly higher value to accomodate surge as a load is switched on and is in series with the load it protects. If you replace a fuse with a higher amp one it will work but create an unsafe circuit. It could cause a failure of the device burn it up, start a fire. The fuse is designed as a safety device. It should not only be the correct amperage but also the correct voltage and fast or slow blow. In other words, if an over-current is allowed - by fitting an incorrect fuse rating, for example - there is a severe risk of an electrical fire. However, it is important to note that, in a healthy circuit, nothing will happen as long as the circuit does not encounter an overload condition. If the circuit does encounter an overload condition then that part of the circuit that the fuse protects may become a fire hazard. Note: Some students have confirmed that the option "Overcurrent might go undetected and cause a fire." was correct in their exams and confirmed that the option "In a healthy system nothing problematic will happen." was not within the available answers. However, we have also received a couple of feedback confirming the correct option to be "In a healthy system nothing problematic will happen." which makes us believe that there are at least two similar question.

content.question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding DC electric motors?
1. If a motor seizes, then the the applied EMF is equal to the back EMF
2. If a motor seizes, then the applied EMF is equal to the net EMF
3. If there is a motor runaway, the applied EMF is equal to the back EMF
4. If there is a motor runaway, the back EMF is equal to the net EMF

options.A: 1 and 3.
options.B: 1 and 4.
options.C: 2 and 3.
options.D: 2 and 4.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.05.02.03: Explain the consequences of the following: rotor seizure; rotor runaway. Back EMF is a backwards voltage that runs through a DC motor armature circuit, and increases with the speed of the motor. It acts like a motor speed regulator. EMF stands for electromotive force, and remember that EMF = voltage. Applied EMF - back EMF = net EMF Input voltage - back EMF = useful voltage Given that EMF increases with rotor speed, when the rotor speed is zero (the motor has yet to spin or has seized), there is no back EMF. Therefore, If a motor seizes, all the applied EMF is able to become net EMF, so applied EMF = net EMF. The opposite occurs if a motor suffers a runaway, where there is no load (therefore no net EMF) applied to slow the motor down. In this case, the high speed of the motor causes an increase in the back EMF, until the back EMF equals the applied EMF. This means the motor has a maximum speed that it can possible turn at, when the back EMF equals the voltage of the circuit.

learning.explanation: A starter-generator combines, as it names suggests, the functions of both the starter and the generator. key_points: Logic gates are a kind of functions that are used in programming and other computer-related devices
An integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output must result
The most common logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate
learning.explanation: Logic gates are a kind of functions that are used in programming and other computer-related devices. An integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output must result. The most common logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate. Both inputs must be 1 to generate a 1. OR gate – Any or All gate. If at least one input is 1, the output will be 1 as well. The output will be 0 only if both inputs are 0. NAND gate – AND gate + NOT = inverted AND output, symbolized by the small circle at the output of the gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOR gate – OR gate + NOT = inverted OR output, symbolized again by the small circle at the output of the OR gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOT gate – invert gate, used to reverse the state of the input. If input = 0, then output = 1.

content.question:
Which of the following statements is correct?

1. By increasing the load on an electric motor (i.e. increasing the resistance against rotation), the power output will increase as a result of an increased current flow
2. The torque of an electrical motor can be calculated by dividing the power by the motor RPM

options.A: 1 and 2 are both correct.
options.B: 1 and 2 are both incorrect.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.

key_points: “1) By increasing the load on an electric motor (i
e
increasing the resistance against rotation), the power output will increase as a result of an increased current flow
learning.explanation: “1) By increasing the load on an electric motor (i.e. increasing the resistance against rotation), the power output will increase as a result of an increased current flow.” Correct. An increased resistance against rotation will result in a slower motor RPM. Consequently, back emf reduces. Such reduction will cause the current to increase. Power output = voltage x current Voltage remains constant, whilst current increases => therefore power will also increase. “2) The torque of an electrical motor can be calculated by dividing the power by the motor RPM.” Correct. In simple words, torque is the twisting force which makes a motor turn. An electrical motor’s torque can be calculated by dividing the power (voltage x current) by the motor RPM: Torque = (Voltage x Current) / RPM

content.question:
Refer to figure.
There is a generator control switch on the flight deck. Using the annex above, which generator does this switch directly control?

options.A: The main generator.
options.B: The tacho generator.
options.C: The exciter generator.
options.D: The permanent magnet generator.

key_points: The diagram shows the "Gen control switch" as highlighted in the annex above
when the generator is switched off, the switch to the left is opened, and activates the solenoid just above, opening the switch above on the voltage control line
This line feeds the exciter generator field coil from the voltage regulator
learning.explanation: The diagram shows the "Gen control switch" as highlighted in the annex above. when the generator is switched off, the switch to the left is opened, and activates the solenoid just above, opening the switch above on the voltage control line. This line feeds the exciter generator field coil from the voltage regulator. When the switch is pushed (off), the exciter generator will no longer produce any current, hence the exciter generator is directly controlled by the switch. The diagram is pretty complex, and does not include absolutely everything about a permanent magnet generator AC alternator, but if you wish to know how it works, the explanation below may help. Brushless AC Alternators (PMG Type) Modern aircraft AC generators are predominantly self-exciting brushless alternators, and often incorporate a permanent magnet generator. To explain this, we are going to work backwards, from what we want our final output to be, to how we get every component of that to work. A generator is made up of a magnetic field (either produced by permanent magnets or by an electric "field" coil which acts like a magnet) and an armature coil. One of those is spinning (rotor) and the other is stationary (stator), and which is which is decided by the input and outputs required. The armature is where AC power is generated, from the rotational energy inputted by the spinning shaft (often from an engine via constant speed drive). The basis of an AC alternator/generator (for AC output they mean the same thing) is that we wish to have the output armature windings on the stator of the main generator, so we can send the AC power straight to the bus bars. This means that the field windings on the main generator must be mounter to the rotor. This main generator is where we make the power to output to the aircraft distribution system. The voltage of the main generator is regulated by changing the strength of the magnetic field, which just means changing the voltage through the field coil. So we somehow need a way to feed voltage-regulated DC power to a spinning coil rotating at 400 Hz. We do this by having a second generator, the exciter generator, mounted on the same shaft, with the rotor this time being the armature coils (and the stator is therefore the magnetic field producer). The spinning armatures generate 3 phase AC current which is sent through a spinning rectifier to produce the field coil for the main generator. The magnetic field for the exciter generator is provided by a DC supply from the voltage regulator. If the voltage output of the main generator drops, the voltage regulator increases the voltage to the exciter field coil, and the voltage of the main generator field will increase, increasing the final output voltage. Initial excitement can be provided by a permanent magnet generator, a third generator on the same shaft, this time with a permanent magnet (field) mounter on the rotor, and the armature (stator) picking up an AC supply, then rectifying it and using it to power the exciter field or the voltage regulator, etc. When the shaft begins spinning, this will be the first thing to produce any current.

key_points: Logic gates are a kind of functions that are used in programming and other computer-related devices

learning.explanation: Logic gates are a kind of functions that are used in programming and other computer-related devices. An integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output must result. The most common logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate. Both inputs must be 1 to generate a 1. OR gate – Any or All gate. If at least one input is 1, the output will be 1 as well. The output will be 0 only if both inputs are 0. NAND gate – AND gate + NOT = inverted AND output, symbolized by the small circle at the output of the gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOR gate – OR gate + NOT = inverted OR output, symbolized again by the small circle at the output of the OR gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOT gate – invert gate, used to reverse the state of the input. If input = 0, then output = 1.

content.question: Circuit breakers are used to protect…

options.A: only DC circuits.
options.B: AC and DC circuits.
options.C: only AC circuits.
options.D: only series-connected circuits.

key_points: Circuit breakers (CBs) combine the function of a fuse and a switch in one unit
They consist of an automatic thermo-sensitive tripping device and a manually or electrically operated switch
Therefore, besides providing protection to an AC or DC circuit, they can be used to switch a circuit on and off under certain circumstances
learning.explanation: Circuit breakers (CBs) combine the function of a fuse and a switch in one unit. They consist of an automatic thermo-sensitive tripping device and a manually or electrically operated switch. Therefore, besides providing protection to an AC or DC circuit, they can be used to switch a circuit on and off under certain circumstances. Circuit breakers are special because even after the circuit breaker has tripped, the circuit can be closed again, thus allowing to restore the circuit and potentially power important systems. We say that the circuit breaker is resettable (which a fuse is not). The most common circuit breakers (CBs) are the bimetallic and magnetic CBs. The bi-metallic CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together. The current flowing through the bonded metals will heat them and make them expand and bend. If the flowing current is too high, the strip will bend so much that it will move a latch, tripping the circuit breaker and opening the circuit. Because the functioning of the bi-metallic CB relays on the time it will take to heat it up, small overcurrents of short duration are allowed, good for some systems but not for others. There are, therefore, other CB types that are more responsive. That’s exactly what a magnetic CB is. An abnormal increase of the circuit's current over the maximum rating will act on an electromagnet in the circuit breaker, pulling a magnetic switch to trip the breaker immediately.

key_points: Circuit breakers are circuit protection devices which can be "reset" if they trip (rather than a fuse which melts)

The bi-metallic (thermal) CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together
learning.explanation: Circuit breakers are circuit protection devices which can be "reset" if they trip (rather than a fuse which melts). The most common circuit breakers (CBs) are the thermal and magnetic CBs. The bi-metallic (thermal) CB consists of two strips of metal bonded together. The current flowing through the bonded metals will heat them and make them expand and bend. If the flowing current is too high for too long, the strip will bend so much that it will move a latch, tripping the circuit breaker and opening the circuit. Because the functioning of the bi-metallic CB relays on the time it will take to heat it up, small overcurrents of short duration are allowed, which is good for some systems but not for others. The higher the overcurrent, the faster the thermal CB will trip. There are, therefore, other CB types that are more responsive. That’s exactly what a magnetic CB is. An abnormal increase of the circuit's current over the maximum rating will act on an electromagnet in the circuit breaker, pulling a magnetic switch (solenoid) to trip the breaker almost instantly. Obviously, it cannot be absolutely instant, as things take time to move and therefore a very short overcurrent will still be experienced by the circuit.

content.question: What will happen if a bus bar has a short circuit? The affected bus...

options.A: is isolated and consumers fed by another generator.
options.B: consumers are no longer fed.
options.C: is transferred to another busbar.
options.D: is transferred to another generator.

key_points: Bus bars are a way of simplifying the distribution of electrical power through a network
They are thick copper bars with holes drilled in, where wiring can be attached to be split to go to other locations/consumers within a network
They can run off one or multiple sources of power, and are much simpler and lighter than individual wiring to every generator/consumer
learning.explanation: Bus bars are a way of simplifying the distribution of electrical power through a network. They are thick copper bars with holes drilled in, where wiring can be attached to be split to go to other locations/consumers within a network. They can run off one or multiple sources of power, and are much simpler and lighter than individual wiring to every generator/consumer. A short circuit is where electricity finds an easier way to flow from high voltage to low voltage. Usually, we want that electricity to flow through our consumer, which has some resistance, but if a significantly easier route exists, the amount of current running through a consumer will decrease, as an easier path exists for the electricity. If, for instance, a loose, uninsulated wire going straight to "ground" touched a bus bar, then all the electricity available to the bus bar would begin to flow through this wire, as it is the easiest path to go from high voltage to low voltage, completing the circuit. This would not only be a fire hazard, as the high current would heat all components up far too much, but would also mean that all connected consumers would not receive any electrical current, and would stop working. Think of it like a "black hole" for electricity, all the current will be sucked down the short circuit and will not feed other consumers. To avoid this eventuality, bus bars have circuit breakers that will disconnect above a certain current. This meant that the bus bar will become isolated from the other circuits in the aircraft, and no more electricity will be lost due to this short circuit. It does, however, mean that the consumers that only take power from that bus bar will be unable to receive power for the rest of the flight.

learning.explanation: The biggest threat to Lithium-ion batteries is thermal runaway. Thermal runaway of the lithium-ion battery initiates an unstoppable chain reaction. key_points: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consists of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier
Therefore it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another
These units are used in situations where AC distribution system needs to supply a DC system
learning.explanation: Transformer Rectifier Units (TRU’s) consists of a unit that combines a transformer and a rectifier. Therefore it converts Alternating Current (AC) into Direct Current (DC) whilst at the same time transforming a certain voltage into another. These units are used in situations where AC distribution system needs to supply a DC system. Batteries work with DC, therefore required the rectifier to convert from AC to DC, and the transformer to provide the correct voltage to charge the battery. The other answers are incorrect: “the AC bus via current limiters” – Current limiters will not change the power from AC to DC, therefore this is incorrect. “a static inverter” – Static inverters are used to convert DC into AC, therefore are not applicable for this scenario. “a DC transformer and rectifier” – A transformer will alter the voltage which could be required, however as mentioned above the rectifier converts AC into DC therefore is not applicable for this scenario.

key_points: The system that checks for faults in the AC generator is the Generator Control Unit (GCU)

Upon detection of a dangerous situation in the generator; which could be over-excitation or overvoltage; the GCU will open the exciter control relay which will protect the generator from potential further damage

learning.explanation: The system that checks for faults in the AC generator is the Generator Control Unit (GCU). Upon detection of a dangerous situation in the generator; which could be over-excitation or overvoltage; the GCU will open the exciter control relay which will protect the generator from potential further damage. At the same time, the GCU will also open the generator circuit breaker (GCB) to disconnect the generator from its bus bar. Should any other command be transmitted from the control panel (except the dog clutch release) it will necessarily pass through the GCU before being executed to the given system. All the modern GCUs can record and provide failure indications at any time.

Housing lithium-ion batteries in a vented metal casing can help to prevent them from becoming a fire hazard by reducing the risk of thermal runaway, which is a condition in which the battery temperature increases rapidly, potentially leading to ignition. The vented casing allows for dissipation of heat and venting of any flammable gases that may be generated during thermal runaway. The other options listed are not effective in preventing lithium-ion batteries from becoming a fire hazard. Installing a fuse on the positive pole of the battery does not address the root cause of thermal runaway, and may not provide adequate protection against ignition. Placing a halon fire extinguisher in the compartment with the battery is not a proactive measure to prevent thermal runaway and may not be able to effectively extinguish a fire that has already started. Continuously charging the battery during flight also does not prevent thermal runaway, and may actually increase the risk of thermal runaway if the battery is overcharged or damaged in some way.

learning.explanation: The X-TIE breaker (DC) allows DC BUS 1 to supply DC BUS 2 and DC BUS 2 to supply DC BUS 1. In normal operations, TRU 2 supplies DC BUS 2 and TRU 1 supplies DC BUS 1. If TRU (1 or 2) fails, DC BUS (1 or 2) can be supplied via the X-TIE link.

options.A: generator is greater than battery voltage and to open when the opposite is true

key_points: When the voltage of the generator is greater than the battery’s voltage, the generator breaker will close in order to supply the batteries with current and charge them
However, when the opposite is true, the reverse current relay will open so that the batteries don’t ‘charge’ the generator
Because they’re only used as a last resort when any other generator fails, the batteries’ current is not be used under normal operation, and even less to provide current to the generators
learning.explanation: When the voltage of the generator is greater than the battery’s voltage, the generator breaker will close in order to supply the batteries with current and charge them. However, when the opposite is true, the reverse current relay will open so that the batteries don’t ‘charge’ the generator. Because they’re only used as a last resort when any other generator fails, the batteries’ current is not be used under normal operation, and even less to provide current to the generators. The amount of current is very limited so in case of emergency, the batteries will only supply a limited number of systems (the most vital). The battery charge limiters will control each battery’s contractor in order to ensure (among others) automatic battery connection for charging, protect them against thermal runaway and short-circuit, and prevent complete discharging when the aircraft is on the ground.

content.question: In the armature of an electric motor, torque is (1)_____ to current and (2)_____ to magnetic field strength.

options.B: (1) proportional; (2) inversely proportional
options.C: (1) inversely proportional; (2) proportional

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.05.02.01: Describe how the torque of an electrical motor is determined by the supplied voltage and current, and the resulting magnetic fields within the motor. The armature is the spinning section of an electric motor. The field coils produce an magnetic field similar to that of a permanent magnet, only stronger, and able to be changed. The armature is the spinning coil(s) of wire that interact with that magnetic field to produce rotational movement. When the electric current in the armature increases, this increases the interaction with the magnetic field and increases torque. Therefore, the current is directly proportional to the torque produced. The magnetic field produced by the field coils also affects the torque. The stronger the magnetic field, the greater the interaction with the current flowing through the armature, so the greater the torque produced. Therefore, the magnetic field strength is also directly proportional to the torque produced. Both these statements are the same, no matter how the motor is wound (in series or in parallel).

content.question: AC generators operated in parallel must have the same…

options.A: frequency and amperage.
options.B: amperage and kVAR.
options.C: voltage and phase.
options.D: voltage and amperage.

key_points: AC generators (otherwise known as alternators) convert mechanical energy into an alternating current

When working in parallel and before connecting, alternators must have equal: Frequency: Damage can occur when there is a difference in frequency, as one generator tries to slow down and the other tries to speed up
Phase sequence: At any point in time, the phases of both generators must be identical (see graph)
learning.explanation: AC generators (otherwise known as alternators) convert mechanical energy into an alternating current. When working in parallel and before connecting, alternators must have equal: Frequency: Damage can occur when there is a difference in frequency, as one generator tries to slow down and the other tries to speed up. Phase sequence: At any point in time, the phases of both generators must be identical (see graph). Voltage: the voltage output of both generators must be equal before being paralleled. Therefore the correct answer is: “Voltage and phase” The other answers are incorrect: “voltage and amperage”: Even though equal voltage is required, the amperage is not required to be equal before paralleling. “amperage and kVAR”: Both the amperage and the kVAR (kilovolt-amperes reactive) are not required to be maintained equal during paralleling of alternators. “Frequency and amperage”: Even though the frequency is required to be constant, amperage is not, therefore this is incorrect.

content.question: What occurs during a DC generator's armature runaway?

options.A: Current decreases in the armature, but because it increases in the commutator, torque remains constant.
options.B: Current decreases in the armature, and because it also decreases in the commutator, torque is reduced.
options.C: Current increases in the armature, and since it also increases in the commutator, torque increases.
options.D: Current increases in the armature, but because it reduces in the commutator, torque is constant.

key_points: When a DC motor suddenly encounters a decrease in load, such as in a runaway situation, the resistance diminishes, causing the rotor (armature) speed to rise
However, this rapid increase in speed poses a risk of motor damage
Instead of converting into shaft rotation, the surplus energy generates heat
learning.explanation: When a DC motor suddenly encounters a decrease in load, such as in a runaway situation, the resistance diminishes, causing the rotor (armature) speed to rise. However, this rapid increase in speed poses a risk of motor damage. Instead of converting into shaft rotation, the surplus energy generates heat. As the mechanical load on the motor decreases, its speed increases, leading to a rise in back electromotive force (EMF). With a higher back EMF, the armature current decreases, thereby diminishing the torque applied to the motor. Torque, which represents the twisting force driving the motor, is measured in Newton-meters (Nm). It is influenced by the voltage, current, and magnetic fields within the motor. A decrease in current results in a reduction in the motor's torque output.

key_points: Fuses and circuit breakers aim to protect every electrical circuit
They prevent the maximum power rating of a component to be exceeded by breaking the circuit if the current increases above that rating
Unlike circuit breakers, fuses cannot be reset after they break the circuit
learning.explanation: Fuses and circuit breakers aim to protect every electrical circuit. They prevent the maximum power rating of a component to be exceeded by breaking the circuit if the current increases above that rating. Unlike circuit breakers, fuses cannot be reset after they break the circuit. There’re 3 types of fuses commonly used in electrical circuits: Cartridge fuse – tubular glass or ceramic body, 2 brass end caps and a tinned copper wire (or silver wire, or pure zinc). High rupture capacity (HRC) – designed for high current rated equipment. Current limiter fuse – high melting point fuses allowing them to carry a significant overload current before rupturing. All fuses have a current-specific rating (in amperes) that will indicate the maximum current they will be able to carry continuously or intermittently without excessively heating and rupturing. The rating of a fuse is designed so that it is not less than the current normally flowing in the circuit, but it ruptures just slightly below the safety limit of the equipment used. A fuse simply consists of a type of wire, as described above, that has a low melting point. As it is placed in series, the excessive electrical load will melt the wire and rupture the flow of current, should it be higher than the fuse’s ampere rating engraved upon it.
