content.question: What should the air/fuel ratio be during a take-off at sea level in a piston engine?

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.08.01.02: State the typical fuel-to-air ratio values or range of values for the above mixtures. For a gasoline (petrol) engine, the chemically correct air/fuel mixture to burn for maximum combustion efficiency is 15:1, so 15 grams of air for each 1 gram of fuel. This is called the stoichiometric ratio. This is not the best mixture to run a piston engine at though, as it leads to very hot combustion and can heat up the cylinders and pistons too much, causing damage. The weaker we run the mixture (more air, less fuel, for instance 16:1), the less fuel there is able to combust, so the engine runs slightly cooler, but produces less power. This is called running "lean of peak", and it is often the most economical way of flying piston engines in the cruise. Running an engine slightly richer than 15:1, say for instance 14:1, gives increased power (but less efficient combustion) due to slightly more fuel available for burning. It is still cooler than running at the chemically correct 15:1 ratio, though, as the extra fuel adds to cooling the engine. Running the mixture full rich, around 10:1 mixture, has a small reduction in maximum power, but gives increased engine reliability as the extra fuel not being burnt is used for engine cooling, and is very effective for keeping the cylinders and pistons cool. It is therefore what we use for take-off and landing, and any changes in power during flight.

content.question: What is a turbocharger used for in a piston aero-engine?

options.A: To compensate for the decrease in MAP with increasing altitude.
options.B: To increase the engine power output with altitude.
options.C: To increase the engine power output at sea level.
options.D: To reduce the stress on all the engine components.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.03: Power-augmentation devices: explain the requirement for power augmentation (turbocharging) of a piston engine. Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.05: Explain the difference between an altitude-boosted turbocharger and a ground-boosted turbocharger. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. Turbochargers are arguably even more useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. We call this an "altitude boosted" turbocharger. They are more useful to us by keeping the same power up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which would put a lot of strain on the engine, which would be a "ground boosted" turbocharger. Turbochargers (and any superchargers, really) increase the amount of air (and therefore fuel) we can ignite in the cylinders, so if we used full turbocharger at take-off, for instance, the forces on the engine would be enormous, and would put too much strain on an engine. We do this in road cars, because we can make engines stronger/heavier, and if they fail it is not life threatening, but with aircraft engines, we cannot afford to gain the extra power for fear of failure, so we simply use it to compensate for the reduction in air density. A turbocharger works by using the excess speed and pressure of the exhaust gasses to spin a turbine, which then directly spins a compressor, which compresses the fresh intake air ready for entry into the cylinders. All superchargers compress fresh intake air like this, but turbochargers are special types of superchargers that use the excess energy leftover in the exhaust gasses that we would not otherwise use.

content.question: In the event of an engine failure during flight in a single-engine aeroplane not fitted with a feathering system, the blades of a constant speed propeller tend to move…

options.A: towards the smallest blade angle by centrifugal twisting moment and/or spring force.
options.B: towards the highest blade angle by oil pressure created by the windmilling propeller.
options.C: to a blade angle dependent on windmilling RPM.
options.D: towards the highest blade angle by the aerodynamic twisting moment.

key_points: When the engine fails, it cannot drive anymore the generators and hydraulic/oil pumps that it would normally supply
Therefore, since the CSU also works on oil pressurized by the engine, it will become inoperative as well
Because of this, only two outside forces will act on the propeller’s blades: the centrifugal and the aerodynamic turning moment
learning.explanation: When the engine fails, it cannot drive anymore the generators and hydraulic/oil pumps that it would normally supply. Therefore, since the CSU also works on oil pressurized by the engine, it will become inoperative as well. Because of this, only two outside forces will act on the propeller’s blades: the centrifugal and the aerodynamic turning moment. The aerodynamic force will tend to move the blade pitch angle towards a coarse pitch, whereas the centrifugal force tends to turn the blade to a fine pitch. Since the centrifugal force is greater than the aerodynamic force, the propeller will be pushed to fine pitch by the centrifugal twisting moment and will create a solid resistive propeller disk that will resist against the relative airflow, creating a lot of drag. Additionally, the system also consists of a speeder spring that is directly linked to the RPM selection controller (blue lever). When there’s no more oil pressure, the spring will automatically move until the fine pitch stop by pushing all the oil out of the propeller hub and resulting in a drop in RPM.

content.question: The application of carburettor heating reduces the…

options.A: Volume of air entering the carburettor, thus enriching the mixture.
options.B: Density of air entering the carburettor, thus enriching the mixture.
options.C: Density of air entering the carburettor, thus leaning the mixture.
options.D: Volume of air entering the carburettor, thus leaning the mixture.

key_points: When applying the carburettor heating, hot air is supplied to the engine
Hot, less dense air will reduce the engine’s power output by roughly 15% and will create a richer mixture
Because the risk of detonation is much higher at high power settings, carburettor heating shouldn’t be selected at power settings greater than 80%
learning.explanation: When applying the carburettor heating, hot air is supplied to the engine. Hot, less dense air will reduce the engine’s power output by roughly 15% and will create a richer mixture. Because the risk of detonation is much higher at high power settings, carburettor heating shouldn’t be selected at power settings greater than 80%. It should be used for a sufficient period of time to restore engine’s original RPM, only when icing conditions are observed along with an unexpected drop in RPM. Bear in mind that when applying the carb’ heat the RPM will initially drop and then increase again provided the accumulated ice has been successfully removed.

content.question: In an engine equipped with a float-type carburettor, the low temperature that causes carburettor ice is normally the result of…

options.A: vaporisation of fuel and expansion of the air in the carburettor
options.B: freezing temperature of the air entering the carburettor
options.C: low volatility of aviation fuel
options.D: compression of air at the carburettor venturi

key_points: The operating principle of float-type carburetors is based on the Bernoulli’s theorem which states that the energy per unit mass of a moving fluid is constant
As the air passes through the convergence of the Venturi duct, its velocity increases causing a drop in pressure and temperature
The pressure will drop proportionally to the mass airflow and is used to make fuel flow from the float chamber by placing a ‘U’-shaped jet into the Venturi
learning.explanation: The operating principle of float-type carburetors is based on the Bernoulli’s theorem which states that the energy per unit mass of a moving fluid is constant. As the air passes through the convergence of the Venturi duct, its velocity increases causing a drop in pressure and temperature. The pressure will drop proportionally to the mass airflow and is used to make fuel flow from the float chamber by placing a ‘U’-shaped jet into the Venturi. Engine suction creates a difference in air pressure at the throat of the Venturi duct and the air inlet resulting in a sucking effect. Besides the drop in pressure and temperature at the Venturi’s throat, the later will increase again within the induction manifold as the throttle is opened. “freezing temperature of the air entering the carburettor” – carburettor icing doesn’t necessarily occur only when freezing temperatures are prevailing. As long as you have visible moisture and the temperature is below +10°C (but also higher under certain conditions), the risk of icing becomes significant. “Low volatility of aviation fuel” – this property is not linked at all to carburetor icing. “Compression of air at the carburettor venturi” – compression will have the opposite reaction, the temperature and pressure will increase. Whereas the venturi decreases the temperature and the pressure of the flowing fuel and air.

content.question: The main advantage of a constant speed propeller compared to a fixed pitch propeller is that a constant speed propeller…

options.A: does not require propeller blade twist.
options.B: has a lower propeller blade stress.
options.C: has a higher maximum propeller efficiency.
options.D: maintains its maximum propeller efficiency over a wider range of airspeeds.

key_points: In a variable pitch propeller, the engine is governed to run at a set rpm throughout the flight range, using the propeller efficiently at all times
The propeller governs the engine at this set rpm by the use of a device known as a constant speed unit (CSU) and by means of a flyweight governor

Any variations in engine power output (throttle pulled back or forward), which would otherwise produce a change in rpm, are sensed by the CSU which alters the propeller pitch angle to keep the rpm constant
learning.explanation: In a variable pitch propeller, the engine is governed to run at a set rpm throughout the flight range, using the propeller efficiently at all times. The propeller governs the engine at this set rpm by the use of a device known as a constant speed unit (CSU) and by means of a flyweight governor. Any variations in engine power output (throttle pulled back or forward), which would otherwise produce a change in rpm, are sensed by the CSU which alters the propeller pitch angle to keep the rpm constant. If the throttle is pulled back, the propeller pitch would automatically decrease (fine pitch) but the RPM will remain the same, and vice-versa. The governor controls a hydraulic servo system feeding high-pressure oil, via a pilot valve, to a piston in the pitch change mechanism (PCM). The CSU operates on the principle of balancing a spring pressure against the centrifugal force of rotating governor flyweights, driven directly from the engine or reduction gearbox. Usually, in a piston engine, the governor flyweights are tensioned by a speeder spring, which is controlled from the cockpit by setting the RPM lever. In a turboprop, however, the most efficient engine RPM is maintained by pre-tensioning the speeder spring to give the maximum engine RPM at all times.

content.question: Aircraft fuel tanks should be checked for water…

options.A: before the first flight of the day because condensation may arise overnight.
options.B: immediately after every refuelling.
options.C: during refuelling.
options.D: before each flight.

key_points: Aviation fuel can only be efficient enough if it is delivered to the engine free of water

Besides the fact that fuel can be delivered to your aircraft tanks already contaminated with water (leaks in the underground tanks, seals, covers), it can also form and/or accumulate in your tanks through various leaks in the vents and seals, or because of improper fuel cap placing that led to precipitation falling in or even condensation
This is why it is recommended that the fuel tanks should be filled as much as practicable overnight
learning.explanation: Aviation fuel can only be efficient enough if it is delivered to the engine free of water. Besides the fact that fuel can be delivered to your aircraft tanks already contaminated with water (leaks in the underground tanks, seals, covers), it can also form and/or accumulate in your tanks through various leaks in the vents and seals, or because of improper fuel cap placing that led to precipitation falling in or even condensation. This is why it is recommended that the fuel tanks should be filled as much as practicable overnight. The indicated correct answer is not wrong since the fuel should be drained before the first flight of the day. However, it is recommended to drain the fuel tanks before your flight as well. You never know where the previous pilot has refueled the airplane and how good is the quality of the fuel there. In the same way, you will never know exactly if the fuel has been drained before the first flight of the day.

content.question: The power output of a diesel engine without a turbo charger is regulated by…

options.A: mixture.
options.B: airflow only.
options.C: fuel flow only.
options.D: fuel flow and airflow.

key_points: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture
For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs

The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder
learning.explanation: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture. For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs. The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder. The fuel injection system consists of atomizers that will spray the fuel into the pre-chamber, but because not all the fuel droplets burn completely, residual soot will remain in the cylinder. To produce enough heat for the mixture to ignite, the diesel engines operate at a much higher compression ratios than the normal petrol engine: from 14:1 up to 28:1 for the most powerful compared to 9:1 for a petrol engine. Because of this high compression ratio, diesel engines also benefit from a higher thermal efficiency. The amount of power delivered will only be determined by the fuel flow. In the same way as for car engines, diesel engines are less powerful than a petrol engine for the same swept volume.

content.question: In a piston engine, the purpose of an altitude mixture control is to…

options.A: enrich the mixture due to decreased air density at altitude.
options.B: weaken the mixture because of reduced exhaust back pressure at altitude.
options.C: prevent a weak mixture when the throttle is opened rapidly at altitude.
options.D: correct for variations in the fuel/air ratio due to decreased air density at altitude.

key_points: The mixture control will allow you to select the amount of fuel that will be mixed with air and go into the engine’s cylinders for combustion and production of mechanical power
At altitude, the density of the air decreases, therefore if the mixture is left fully rich as it should be during the climb phase, the mixture will be too rich for the cruise phase
Therefore, the pilot will use the mixture control lever to correct for variations in the fuel/air ratio encountered at higher altitudes
learning.explanation: The mixture control will allow you to select the amount of fuel that will be mixed with air and go into the engine’s cylinders for combustion and production of mechanical power. At altitude, the density of the air decreases, therefore if the mixture is left fully rich as it should be during the climb phase, the mixture will be too rich for the cruise phase. Therefore, the pilot will use the mixture control lever to correct for variations in the fuel/air ratio encountered at higher altitudes.

content.question: To enable proper functioning of a piston engine during rapid throttle advance a carburettor is fitted with:

options.A: a mixture control.
options.B: a diffuser (compensating jet).
options.C: a power jet.
options.D: an accelerator pump.

key_points: The function of an accelerator pump in the carburettor of a piston engine is to enable proper functioning of a piston engine during rapid throttle advance
In fact, a rapid throttle advance will translate into an abrupt huge air intake into the carburettor
However, the fuel metering unit of the carburettor is not as responsive, so there will be less fuel than air, which will result in a temporary weak mixture
learning.explanation: The function of an accelerator pump in the carburettor of a piston engine is to enable proper functioning of a piston engine during rapid throttle advance. In fact, a rapid throttle advance will translate into an abrupt huge air intake into the carburettor. However, the fuel metering unit of the carburettor is not as responsive, so there will be less fuel than air, which will result in a temporary weak mixture. The accelerator pump is mechanically linked to the throttle, so as soon as it is moved, the pump will force fuel into the venturi to achieve the right mixture for the given throttle setting.

content.question: Comparing a fuel injection system to a fuel carburettor system for a piston engine, the fuel injection system…

options.A: is less prone to induction-system icing.
options.B: increases the chances of cylinders overheating due to uneven fuel distribution.
options.C: has a worsened fuel economy.
options.D: has a decreased acceleration response.

They work on the principle of feeding fuel under pressure to the engine, therefore they don’t need a venturi in the air intake
Without any ducts that inevitably reduce the temperature by their nature, the fuel injection systems are less prone to air intake icing than the traditional carburetor fuel systems
learning.explanation: Fuel injection systems provide uniform and reliable fuel delivery, better icing protection, and quicker throttle response. They work on the principle of feeding fuel under pressure to the engine, therefore they don’t need a venturi in the air intake. Without any ducts that inevitably reduce the temperature by their nature, the fuel injection systems are less prone to air intake icing than the traditional carburetor fuel systems.

content.question: After an engine failure on a twin-engined aircraft, which of the following configurations will put the least strain on the rudder?

options.A: A forward CG and no slip indication.
options.B: A forward CG and the 1/2 slip ball deflection towards the operative engine.
options.C: A forward CG and 1/2 slip ball deflection towards the inoperative engine.
options.D: An aft CG and no slip indication.

key_points: Note: This should really be a Principle of Flight question, but we have feedback that it is being asked in AGK also
Any further exam feedback is always useful, and can be put in the comments or emailed directly to info@atplquestions
com, thank you
learning.explanation: Note: This should really be a Principle of Flight question, but we have feedback that it is being asked in AGK also. Any further exam feedback is always useful, and can be put in the comments or emailed directly to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. This is very similar to question 214523, but asking about the other end of the spectrum. CG CONSIDERATIONS Firstly, we are looking for anything that either decreases the yawing moment caused by the engine failure (which we would usually have to counteract using the rudder), or anything that increases the effectiveness of our rudder, so we would have to use less of it to produce the same effect. Initially, we can say that the further forward our centre of gravity (CG), the larger the moment arm from the rudder to the CG, and the more effective our rudder is. Therefore, our rudder is most effective at a forward CG and we would need to put less stress through it to produce the same amount of moment. SIDESLIP Next, we have to consider the sideslip configuration of the aircraft, as well as how that is indicated on our instruments. Remember that the sideslip ball indicator is not useful in the usual sense when we have an engine failure, as it only really measures the direction of the "local gravity", the G-forces on the aircraft. 1) First consider wings-level flight. The moment (turning force) of the asymmetric thrust must be counteracted by the rudder, which makes the aircraft maintain its heading, but causes it to track with a sideslip towards the dead engine (meaning that the airflow is coming at the aircraft from the side of the dead engine). This requires a lot of rudder to maintain, and leaves us in a sideslip condition with a lot of drag. Our sideslip ball indicator will be central in this configuration, therefore, even though this is a sideslip condition, it has "no slip indication" 2) Banking towards the live engine A small bank angle towards the operative engine (up to 5° AoB, "five to the live") can reduce or even remove the sideslip using the weight of the aircraft to counteract the tendency to fly away from the live engine. It is a commonly used configuration to acquire slightly more aircraft performance during an engine failure, but not too much bank angle, as that begins to negate the effect and reduce performance again. This reduces the required moment of the rudder (mostly because it is no longer having to fight the weather-cocking effect of the fin and aft fuselage) This reduces the aircraft's actual sideslip but a slip ball indicator would show approximately 1/2 a ball deflection to the operative engine. This is because there is no turning force and so the only G-force that the ball detects is straight down, and as we are banked, that means slightly towards whichever way we have banked (the live engine). Therefore, the correct answer to cause the least strain on the rudder is to have a forward CG and 1/2 ball slip indication towards the operative engine (aircraft banked slightly towards the live engine).

content.question: If the manifold pressure gauge of a piston engine shows an increase shortly after carburettor heat is turned on, it indicates that…

options.A: excessive heat is being used.
options.B: ice was forming in carburettor.
options.C: the mixture was too lean.
options.D: the cylinder walls are overheating.

key_points: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature)
The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure
This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure)
learning.explanation: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature). The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure. This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure). Therefore, as soon as the carburetor heating is turned on, the ice buildup will melt, and the duct will see an increase in static pressure (=manifold pressure).

content.question: In a dry sump system, the (1) _____ pump has a (2) _____ volume compared to the (3) _____ pump to make sure that the engine sump remains dry.

options.A: (1) scavenge; (2) smaller; (3) pressure
options.B: (1) scavenge; (2) larger; (3) pressure
options.C: (1) pressure; (2) larger; (3) scavenge
options.D: (1) pressure; (2) smaller; (3) scavenge

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.02: Describe the working principle of a dry-sump lubrication system and describe the functions of the following components: oil tank (reservoir) and its internal components: hot well, de-aerator, vent, expansion space; check valve (non-return valve); pressure pump and pressure-relief valve; scavenge pump; filters (suction, pressure and scavenge); oil cooler; oil cooler bypass valve (anti-surge and thermostatic); pressure and temperature sensors; lines. A dry sump engine is one where the oil is not allowed to sit in the engine sump for too long, and is instead "scavenged" back to a separate reservoir. This is the opposite of a "wet sump" engine, where the sump (within the engine casing) is the reservoir, and a lot less systems are required, but with reduced engine power due to losses. With a dry sump engine, the oil enters from the reservoir via a pressure pump (along with filters, coolers, and some sensors), getting it up to a suitable pressure to spray inside the engine. The oil then lubricates, cools and cleans the engine components, finally ending up at the bottom of the engine, where it gathers in the sump, and is collected up by a scavenge pump (more filters as well), which returns it to the reservoir. The oil is often quite aerated and foamy by this point, so is less dense, and the scavenge pump needs a larger volume to cope with this oil, and not let it mount up in the sump. The scavenge pump also needs to be a higher volume than the pressure pump, as the other way around would force more and more oil into the engine, and would create a potential flooding of the sump, which is supposed to hold oil only for a short amount of time, potentially damaging the engine by having too much oil.

content.question: What is the best method to stop a running engine if the magneto switch ground wire becomes disconnected?

options.A: Lean out mixture until engine backfires and stops.
options.B: Feather the propeller.
options.C: No special method is required, if the wire becomes disconnected the engine will stop.
options.D: Shut off fuel.

key_points: Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch
The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth
In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded
learning.explanation: Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch. The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth. In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded. However, if the grounding wire is broken, the magneto will keep working normally and the engine will continue running. Another situation where the engine can keep running is when an excessive carbon deposit has formed in the cylinder head. Because the deposit is still hot enough when you arrive at your parking position after the flight in order to ignite the charge without the spark from the plugs. The effect will be a hardly rumbling engine that is still running. If this ever happens and the engine doesn’t stop, you can simply pull back the mixture control lever (red) and shut off the fuel supply. Caution! Maintenance action should be sought before touching the propeller since the engine can start at any time with one magneto still un-grounded.

content.question: Where is the engine oil stored in a wet-sump oil system?

options.A: The bottom of the engine.
options.B: A seperate tank.
options.C: Inside the engine cylinders.
options.D: There is no oil storage.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.03: Describe a wet-sump lubrication system. There are two main types of oil system for engines, dry-sump and wet-sump. The biggest difference between the two is where the oil stored when not in use. In a dry-sump system, the oil is pumped from the bottom of the engine to the oil reservoir. In a wet-sump system, the oil is stored in the "sump", which is just the area at the bottom of the engine, where the oil naturally drains to. There are advantages and disadvantages to both. Wet-sump systems are quite common on ground vehicle engines and older aircraft engines, as they are less complex than dry-sump systems, and therefore are less prone to failure. They do have a fair few disadvantages, though. These include not being able to properly oil the engine during some aerobatic manoeuvres, and a reduced amount of oil capacity, and reduced cooling capacity, due to the oil only being stored in the bottom of the engine. There are also some small performance losses due to more oil splashing about in the bottom of the engine.

content.question: A turbocharger system in a reciprocating engine is normally driven by…

options.A: an electrically-activated hydraulically-powered clutch.
options.B: an electric motor.
options.C: an hydraulic motor.
options.D: the exhaust system.

key_points: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude
The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor
The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller
learning.explanation: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude. The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor. The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller. That energy is nothing else than exhaust gases. The turbocharger consists of two exhaust gas inlets that receive and direct the exhaust gases towards the turbine wheel. The exhaust gases mechanically spin the turbine before leaving the system through an exhaust gas outlet. The turbine is connected through a solid common shaft to a compressor, and the rotating energy gained from the exhaust gases circulation will serve to drive the compressor. At the compressor’s end, there’s also an inlet that will receive and direct ambient air to the compressor’s impeller eye. The air will then leave the impeller almost at a tangent to the periphery and trade velocity for an increase in pressure and temperature. The boost air under pressure obtained from this process will then be ducted to mix with the fuel and follow its path towards combustion. The pressure of the compressed air (boost) can be monitored only on the cockpit MAP gauge.

content.question: A piston engine aeroplane with a fixed pitch propeller is flying at normal cruising speed when one magneto fails completely. The initial response of the engine is…

options.A: a significant increase in cylinder head temperature.
options.B: excessive vibration.
options.C: an additional load on the other magneto.
options.D: a loss of approximately 100 RPM.

key_points: The ignition system is duplicated so both halves must be fully operative to ensure a safe handling of the engine should one of them fail during flight
This is why you have to perform a magneto check before departure, also called mag drop
You will perform this twice, at different power settings: idle and about 75% of maximum
learning.explanation: The ignition system is duplicated so both halves must be fully operative to ensure a safe handling of the engine should one of them fail during flight. This is why you have to perform a magneto check before departure, also called mag drop. You will perform this twice, at different power settings: idle and about 75% of maximum. After you set your engine at one of these power settings, you will switch off each magneto in turn and check that the RPM drops within specific limits (usually 100 RPM) and the engine runs smoothly. As a result you will find out that if one of the magnetos fails during flight, engine power is not significantly compromised. If, however, during the mag drop checks you notice that the engine stops it would indicate that one half of the magnetos isn’t properly working, whereas if there’s no drop in RPM it means that one half of the ignition system is not being earthed and maintenance support should be seek.

content.question: Which of the following may be controlled by FADEC in a piston engine?

options.A: The mixture ratio and ignition timing.
options.B: Carburettor heat and spark plug voltage.
options.C: Cooling and lubrication.
options.D: Magneto operation and the impulse coupling starter.

key_points: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) FADEC is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing most efficient power settings through single lever operation

It allows many hundreds of sensor inputs to be fed to the central computer, an EEC (electronic engine controller) or ECU (engine control unit), which then calculates the best outputs for performance and efficiency, and can automatically make such inputs
It has control over every available part of the engine, from fuel-air mixture to ignition timing and even the propeller controller for variable pitch propellers
learning.explanation: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) FADEC is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing most efficient power settings through single lever operation. It allows many hundreds of sensor inputs to be fed to the central computer, an EEC (electronic engine controller) or ECU (engine control unit), which then calculates the best outputs for performance and efficiency, and can automatically make such inputs. It has control over every available part of the engine, from fuel-air mixture to ignition timing and even the propeller controller for variable pitch propellers. Ignition timing is the point in the 4 stroke engine cycle where the air/fuel mixture is ignited, and as RPM increases, the ignition timing should get earlier in the cycle to provide best efficiency. In a diesel engine this is the point where the fuel is injected, as it immediately ignites. The advantages of FADEC on piston engines include: Reduced weight Optimum efficiency No possibility of exceeding engine limitations Easy engine diagnostics There are also disadvantages to FADEC, which include: High complexity 2 ECUs are required to avoid a single point of failure No ability to gain excess power out of the engine in a crisis (e.g. terrain escape) Complete electrical failure means an engine failure (or uncontrollable engines)

content.question: When detonation is recognised in a piston engine, the correct procedure is to…

options.A: increase manifold pressure and fully enrich the mixture.
options.B: reduce manifold pressure and lean the mixture.
options.C: reduce manifold pressure and fully enrich the mixture.
options.D: increase manifold pressure and lean the mixture.

key_points: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that it ignites spontaneously at an early stage of the power stroke
In fact, the rate of pressure rise will occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to move downwards
Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat
learning.explanation: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that it ignites spontaneously at an early stage of the power stroke. In fact, the rate of pressure rise will occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to move downwards. Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat. The cylinder walls, the piston’s head, the sparking plugs and the exhaust valves are being hardly damaged when detonation occurs as this will cause a sudden knock. The conditions in which detonation is most likely in a piston engine are a high manifold pressure leading to a high cylinder head temperature and low RPM. The risk of detonation can be reduced by: First of all, always using the correct grade of fuel designed for your aircraft’s engine. Using a toolow octane rating will greatly increase the likelihood of detonation. Making sure the proper mixture is being supplied to the engine in any conditions. The greater the amount of fuel for a given amount of air, the greater the power that can be obtained without detonation. Avoid situations where the temperature and pressure of the mixture raise before it burns, such as applying carburetor heating at high power settings (takeoff/climb). However, if you ever experience detonation during flight, the following corrective action should be carried: Reduce the manifold pressure (= retard the throttle) Fully enrich the mixture.

options.A: oil temperature
options.B: C.H.T. (cylinder head temperature)
options.C: cabin temperature

Along with a cowl flap or gills, it will avoid to have excessive cooling over the cylinders situated at the front of the engine in comparison to those situated slightly backwards
Because of the lower maintenance costs, the ram air cooling is the preferred method to cool the simple general aviation aircraft

Along with a cowl flap or gills, it will avoid to have excessive cooling over the cylinders situated at the front of the engine in comparison to those situated slightly backwards. Because of the lower maintenance costs, the ram air cooling is the preferred method to cool the simple general aviation aircraft.

content.question: A waste gate controls the output of a turbocharger by varying the amount of exhaust gasses passing through the turbocharger's (1) _____. A fully (2) _____ waste gate will achieve the maximum turbocharger RPM.

options.A: (1) turbine; (2) open
options.B: (1) compressor; (2) open
options.C: (1) compressor; (2) closed
options.D: (1) turbine; (2) closed

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.04: Describe the function and the principle of operation of the following main components of a turbocharger: turbine; compressor; waste gate; waste-gate actuator. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. Turbochargers are arguably even more useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. They are more useful to us by keeping the same power up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which puts a lot of strain on the engine. A turbocharger works by using the speed and pressure of the exhaust gasses to spin a turbine, which then uses that energy to spin the compressor, which compresses the fresh intake air ready for entry into the cylinders. We cannot allow the turbocharger to run wild though, as too much pressure (MAP) can cause the engine to "overboost", and even fail quite spectacularly. The way we regulate the turbocharger is by varying how much air gets to the turbine, this is via a wastegate system. the exhaust gasses can go down two different tubes, one is a standard exhaust, straight out of the aircraft (bypassing the turbine). The other is a tube to the turbine, to spin up the turbocharger. The wastegate is a butterfly valve that can block the exhaust tube, so when it is closed, all the exhaust gasses go to the turbine, making the compressor/turbine spin fastest. When the engine reaches its maximum MAP, the oil system which regulates the wastegate begins to open it, letting some of the "waste" air straight out of the aircraft, so it does not continue to run the turbine, which might overboost the engine.

content.question: A piston engine compression ratio is the ratio of the…

options.A: total volume to the swept volume.
options.B: clearance volume to the swept volume.
options.C: swept volume to the clearance volume.
options.D: total volume to the clearance volume.

key_points: The compression ratio is the ratio of the largest volume (total volume) to the smallest volume (clearance volume)
In other words, it is the ratio between the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the BDC to the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the TDC
When the piston is at TDC, the fuel/air mixture is compressed into a very small space between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder
learning.explanation: The compression ratio is the ratio of the largest volume (total volume) to the smallest volume (clearance volume). In other words, it is the ratio between the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the BDC to the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the TDC. When the piston is at TDC, the fuel/air mixture is compressed into a very small space between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder. This is generally labeled as the clearance volume, or to put it simply, the smallest volume. On the other hand, when the piston is at the BDC, the volume of space containing the mixture (the total volume) is much larger. The difference between the total volume and the clearance volume is called the swept volume.

content.question: Which of the following is true with regards to a wet-sump oil system?

options.A: The oil is pumped from the reservoir to the engine for lubrication and cooling.
options.B: The oil reservoir is within the engine casing.
options.C: The oil is stored outside the aircraft, in a separate tank, to avoid contamination.
options.D: The oil reservoir is located in the main rotor gearbox.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.03: Describe a wet-sump lubrication system. There are two main types of oil system for engines, dry-sump and wet-sump. The biggest difference between the two is where the oil stored when not in use. In a dry-sump system, the oil is pumped from the bottom of the engine to the external oil reservoir and then pumped back to the engine to work again. In a wet-sump system, the oil is stored in the "sump", which is just the area at the bottom of the engine crankcase, where the oil naturally drains to. There are advantages and disadvantages to both. Wet-sump systems are quite common on ground vehicle engines and older aircraft engines, as they are less complex than dry-sump systems, and therefore are less prone to failure. They do have a fair few disadvantages, though. These include not being able to properly oil the engine during some aerobatic manoeuvres, and a reduced amount of oil capacity, and reduced cooling capacity, due to the oil only being stored in the bottom of the engine. There are also some small performance losses due to more oil splashing about in the bottom of the engine.

content.question: The use of carburettor heating during take-off and climb is discouraged because of the…

options.A: Impossibility of engine supplying enough heat.
options.B: Increased drag.
options.C: Loss of power and increased risk of detonation.
options.D: Risk of fire.

key_points: Carburettor heating reduces the air density of the air entering the engine
Consequently, the mass flow decreases and so does engine performance
Due to the decrease of engine power, carburettor heating is normally not used during take-off and climb power settings
learning.explanation: Carburettor heating reduces the air density of the air entering the engine. Consequently, the mass flow decreases and so does engine performance. Due to the decrease of engine power, carburettor heating is normally not used during take-off and climb power settings. Especially important when taking off from short fields, you want all the power your engine has to offer, as carb heat robs your engine of some power. If you have carb ice, applying carb heat will cause your engine to make even less power (hot air is less dense than cold air).

content.question: Viscosity is…

options.A: the temperature dependence of an oil.
options.B: the pressure resistance of an oil.
options.C: the flow velocity inside the oil lines.
options.D: the tendency of a liquid or gas to resist flow.

key_points: Viscosity, also known as fluid’s internal friction, is the tendency of a liquid or gas to resist flow and is temperature-dependent
When oil is cold, it has a high viscosity and flows slowly, thus making the fluid stream quite difficult

However, if the fluid’s temperature increases, the viscosity might become excessively low to the point where the film between the bearing surfaces breaks down and metal-to-metal contact occurs, resulting in rapid wear, overheating, and ultimately fire
learning.explanation: Viscosity, also known as fluid’s internal friction, is the tendency of a liquid or gas to resist flow and is temperature-dependent. When oil is cold, it has a high viscosity and flows slowly, thus making the fluid stream quite difficult. However, if the fluid’s temperature increases, the viscosity might become excessively low to the point where the film between the bearing surfaces breaks down and metal-to-metal contact occurs, resulting in rapid wear, overheating, and ultimately fire.

content.question: When comparing petrol engines with diesel engines, petrol engines..

options.A: Have a lower compression ratio than diesel engines.
options.B: Have an injection system; diesel engines have a carburettor.
options.C: Are compression ignition engines; diesel engines have a glow plug for ignition.
options.D: Have a lower specific fuel consumption than diesel engines.

key_points: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture
For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions), and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs

The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder
learning.explanation: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture. For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions), and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs. The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder. The fuel injection system consists of atomizers that will spray the fuel into the pre-chamber, but because not all the fuel droplets burn completely, residual soot will remain in the cylinder. To produce enough heat for the mixture to ignite, the diesel engines operate at much higher compression ratios than the normal petrol engine: from 14:1 up to 28:1 for the most powerful compared to 9:1 for a petrol engine. Because of this high compression ratio, diesel engines also benefit from higher thermal efficiency. The amount of power delivered will only be determined by the fuel flow. In the same way, as for car engines, diesel engines are less powerful than a petrol engine for the same swept volume.

content.question: There is a gradual loss of oil from the engine lubrication system. Which of the following indications can be expected as a result of this leak?

options.A: Low/fluctuating oil pressure, low oil temperature.
options.B: High/fluctuating oil pressure, low oil temperature.
options.C: Low/fluctuating oil pressure, high oil temperature.
options.D: High/fluctuating oil pressure, high oil temperature.

key_points: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts
It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal
Piston engines are very dependent on their lubrication oil
learning.explanation: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts. It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal. Piston engines are very dependent on their lubrication oil. Serious damage will occur quickly through overheating (and eventually fire) or failure of the lubrication system; therefore, the limitations should be strictly observed. Frequent checks should be made of the oil temperature and pressure, and the power should be adjusted when necessary to keep them within limits.

content.question: Assume an initial condition at a high cruise altitude with a constant speed propeller. What will happen if the altitude is decreased while the throttle remains fully open and the waste gate is seized in the cruise position?

options.A: The power of the engine will decrease.
options.B: The manifold absolute pressure (MAP) value will stay constant.
options.C: The manifold absolute pressure (MAP) value may exceed the maximum allowed value.
options.D: The blade angle may reach the full fine limit.

key_points: The waste gate is a butterfly valve located in the exhaust flow, upstream of the turbocharger, and controlled by a separate hydraulic actuator
It is connected in parallel with the turbocharger
A constant MAP at the diffuser stage (after leaving the impeller) can be maintained by controlling the amount of gas directed to the turbine
learning.explanation: The waste gate is a butterfly valve located in the exhaust flow, upstream of the turbocharger, and controlled by a separate hydraulic actuator. It is connected in parallel with the turbocharger. A constant MAP at the diffuser stage (after leaving the impeller) can be maintained by controlling the amount of gas directed to the turbine. The waste gate hydraulic actuator is continuously supplied with engine oil and returns back to the engine through a variable restrictor. When the restrictor is closed, the actuator will be pressurized with engine oil pressure, that will force the actuator’s piston to move, and thus closing the waste gate. When the waste gate fully closes, it directs all the exhaust gases to the turbine, causing it to accelerate. This is exactly what will happen at a high cruising altitude. The waste gate will be fully closed, and the turbine will accelerate to its maximum causing an excessive increase in pressurized air, and thus, a potential exceedance of the maximum allowed MAP.

content.question: What is the purpose of cowl flaps on an aeroplane?

options.A: Air flow across the engine is reduced when they are open, which decreases cooling efficiency.
options.B: Air flow into the engine air intake is decreased when they are open, which decreases engine performance.
options.C: Air flow across the engine is increased when they are open, which increases cooling efficiency.
options.D: Air flow into the engine air intake is increased when they are open, which increases engine performance.

key_points: Air-cooled reciprocating engines use ram air from the atmosphere to cool the cylinders and all the other critical heated engine parts
The cylinders’ outside structure is made of fins to increase the surface in contact with the cool air, thus improving the cooling effect
The ram air is derived from the propeller slipstream and the aircraft’s forward movement through the air
learning.explanation: Air-cooled reciprocating engines use ram air from the atmosphere to cool the cylinders and all the other critical heated engine parts. The cylinders’ outside structure is made of fins to increase the surface in contact with the cool air, thus improving the cooling effect. The ram air is derived from the propeller slipstream and the aircraft’s forward movement through the air. In order to properly spread the cool ram air over each cylinder and reduce the drag generated the engine is cowled. Along with a cowl flap or gills, it will avoid having excessive cooling over the cylinders situated at the FRONT of the engine in comparison to those situated slightly backward. Because of the lower maintenance costs, ram air cooling is the preferred method to cool the simple general aviation aircraft.
